attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description:
A physical stock take was conducted on 08.04.2025 with the aim of establishing whether internal controls were effective and whether physical stock items were matching with those in the SAP system. 

         After stock take, it was noted that most stock items had nil variations with exception to;

  •         Bread stock had +92.75 pieces cumulatively

  •        Poly bags had a variance of -1,025 pieces cumulatively

  •        Wheat bran variance of +1.009 kgs

  •        Yeast 25gms -10.536gms

        Details of the findings were as illustrated  in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should maintain stock controls and enhance control of polybags variety wise so as to reduce variances hence cumulative variance. Accounts should adjust the balance of 25gms yeast which is appearing in the system.
attributes.effect: Stocks were well controlled as depicted by minimal variances noted with exception to 25gms yeast which was in the system but physically was not present
attributes.remediation_plan: Enhanced control of polybags usage should be done so as to eliminate variance noted. Adjustment of a 25gms yeast should be done in the system to remove it.

value: Stock is well controlled. Variance noted in polybags was as a result of the many varieties we have in the branch. We will request accounts to adjust the yeast and remove the 25gms from the system

The branch stocks are well controlled.

         Variation of poly bags might have been due to mix up in the store. NB; Poly bags stock on date 14th April reflected an excess of 1,105 pcs.

In a prior audit report dated 5th March 2025 polybags had a variance of -1,151 pieces, finished product had a variance of +15 Loaves and GIT had 1,150 loaves from Karatina branch yet to be physically received as at stock take time.
Current
This test entails doing a physical stock take for raw materials and packing materials then comparing with SAP system balances
From the analysis of stock, polybags had a cumulative shortfall of 1,025 pcs. Adjustment for a 25gms yeast should be done in the system as it is not received nor used in the branch
Operations/Production Department
The main objective of this test is to check if all stock are well controlled and there are no variances

attributes.title: Bread Weight Check
attributes.description:
Bread produced and packed in the branch were weighed randomly to determine if bread dispatched to the market was of the correct weight.

         From the sample selected audit noted that all varieties weighed had underweight cases as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: Spot checks should be enhanced to ensure all production parameters are followed so as to eliminate cases of underweight. Slicers should be asked to pack bread as per production so that those overlooked do not overcool.
attributes.effect: Underweight bread dispatched to market exposes the company to risk of penalties if they are intercepted by the weight and measures officials.
attributes.remediation_plan:
Investigate why underweight loaves are occurring and whether they were as a result of:

  • Incorrect dough portioning
  • Improper fermentation (dough not rising properly)
  • Oven or baking inconsistencies
  • Human error in scaling
  • Equipment malfunction or wear (e.g., scales, dividers)

value: We will enhance spot checks in all production areas to ensure all production procedures are followed so as to minimize cases of underweight bread in the branch

Spot checks are being contacted frequently and awareness meetings with supervisors and bakery staffs on how to make sure/control underweights.

         Slicers are   encouraged to enhance speed which in most cases leads to overcooling. Supervisors have always been encouraged to monitor packaging to be done as per production to make sure no delay in packaging.
In a prior audit report the follow were underweight cases; ML-53%, 8BT-55%, 4CTW-7%, 4Long-9% & 4SN-7%
Current
The test entails weighing bread selected randomly from packed bread variety wise
All varieties weighed had underweight cases meaning that customers were receiving bread which had less weight the expected
Operations/Production Department
The test is meant to check  cases of underweight or overweight in the branch

attributes.title: Bread Damages Check
attributes.description:
An analysis of production and market/supermarket damages was done to determine whether they were within the allowed percentage of 0.2% to total production and 0.5% of total sales respectively.

         A sample period of 39 days (1 March 2025 to 8 April 2025) was used to analyse bread damages. Audit noted that the percentage of average production damages stood at 0.23% of the total production while average market damages was 0.39% of total sales as per manager’s book as illustrated in the table below;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

         A further comparison of bread damages recorded by the branch manager with those in SAP system from 1st March 2025 to 8th April 2028 was checked so ascertain if they were tallying.

        From the analysis it was noted that market damages had  variances as illustrated in the table below;

 

 

 

 

 

    

          From the analysis the manager was not recording supermarket returns in the branch bread damages book.

Damages sent to Ingredients

         For the same period damages sent to ingredients was more by 40.65kgs or 101.625 pieces of loaves worth Ksh 5,386 as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should control production of bread so as to minimize damages.

         The manager should be recording supermarket returns on daily basis so that his records tally with those in system. Sending more damages to ingredients should be controlled by recording all damages and making follow up on daily basis
attributes.effect:
Production damages were above set limit meaning the company lost revenue through excess damages amounting to Ksh 14,593 [(0.03*2,111/0.23)*53]

         With the two records having different figures it implies that recording of damages was not being done accurately by the branch manager

         Sending more damages means that there were those which were never recorded.
attributes.remediation_plan: Enhance control in production section to minimize cases of bread damages

value:
We will try our level best to control and reduce production damages. I will be recording supermarket returns

I will be counter checking damages recorded against those weighed to see if they do match on a daily basis so as to address issue of sending more damages

Production damages are a bit high due to worn out 400gm ct tins whereby replacement is in the process.

Variance of damages sent to ingredient department was noted and manager advised to make sure damages from supermarkets are recorded in the damages control book.
In a prior audit report average production bread damages stood at 0.23% of total loaves produced while market damages stood at 0.51% of total sales

From the analysis production were above set upper limit and the branch had sent more damages to ingredients department

The branch manager was not recording all supermarket damages
Operations/Production Department

This test is intended to:

  • Check if set production and market damages upper limits of 0.2% of total loaves produced and 0.5% of totals respectively are not surpassed.
  • Check if damages sent to ingredient are matching with those recorded by the branch manager

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description:
A spot check in the cash office was carried out with the aim of ensuring cash at hand was tallying with that of the cash flow balance.

         It was noted that the cashier fully accounted for the expected cash balance of Ksh 692 as at 10.04.25. At the time of cash count there were IOUs for Ksh 14,530 in the name of Francis Omullo-Mechanic

         Note: As per payment vouchers for date 5/3/2025 total amount to be paid to casual was Ksh 49,598. However, as per the cash flow Ksh 48,690 was cashed out which resulted to a variance of Ksh 908. The Ksh 908 need to be cashed out. There were other cases but they were rectified. For instance on 18/3/25 second shift Nicholas Murajiri was indicated as a casual in the payment voucher but because the cashier has been in the branch he cancelled it and informed the supervisor to record the voucher accurately.
attributes.recommendation:
The cashier should maintain the controls. A follow up should be made so that the IOUs are cleared.

         The supervisors should write payment vouchers accurately so that in case of new cashier is posted in the branch payment of casual is smooth.
attributes.effect:
Company’s money was adequately safeguarded. IOUs should be cleared within a given time frame so as they are not used as a loophole to misplace company cash.

The issue of over or under payment of casuals was as a result of wrongly writing payment vouchers.
attributes.remediation_plan: To ensure cash out is done accurately, the supervisors should ensure recording is clear and the manager reconfirm the same

value: Cash was well controlled. I will ask the supervisors to record payment vouchers accurately.

The cashier is good and competent in cash controls. The iou of 14,530 which was for vehicle repairs was cleared.

 All supervisors have been advised to make sure no permanent staff is indicated as a casual.
Current
This is the process of maintaining cash balances in the branch on daily basis after each day's activity and reconciliation
From the analysis, the payment vouchers should be rechecked to ensure payment to casuals is well captured  as it was noted there were lapses in other days where cash out was not done accurately
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtors analysis
attributes.description:
Outstanding debts were analysed as at 12 April 2025 to check the magnitude.

         It was observed that schools had an outstanding balance of Ksh 1,707,837.45 while route customers had balances amounting to Ksh 249,501.50 as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: A follow up should be made to recover the amounts marked as defaulted by the sales rep.
attributes.effect: The company is exposed to risk of losing its revenue highlighted in yellow as they have defaulted.
attributes.remediation_plan: Follow up should be made to ensure customers and institutions with debt do pay

value: Sales rep is following up with balances and those with security deposit will be asked to sign withdrawal forms so as to repay outstanding debt.

Sales rep and R.S.M are following up with payments.

Route customers with debts have high security deposits and extra cents compared to their debts and most of them are alternating customers.
In a prior audit report total customers outstanding debts was Ksh73,831
Current
Sales Department

attributes.title: Analysis of Branch Yield (Mixing Chart Analysis)
attributes.description:
Mixing charts and mixing chart summaries from 1 March 2025 to 8 April 2025 were examined to find out the branch’s utto consumption, average yield, cases of remix and summation of totals

         After examining the records the follow were noted;

  •         Average yield per bag was190.79loaves per bag.

  •        Utto consumption was at 100%.

  •        There were 12 tins of remix during the period

  •         Average production was 122.46 bags per day representing 78.50% of target which is 156 bags per day (Branch Capacity).

        The table below illustrates the findings;

Note: During the period (01.03.25 – 08.04.25) the branch borrowed 29,109 pieces of loaves which is on average 4 bags per day [(29,109/39)/190]
attributes.recommendation: On those days the branch run on full capacity, the branch management should ensure production target is achieved so that they don’t borrow bread from other branches
attributes.effect: Target production in bags was not achieved meaning the branch’s capacity was under utilized
attributes.remediation_plan: yield was being achieved hence this should be maintained. in terms of production target achievement the branch was not achieving this hence borrowing bread. Therefore, to improve on this the branch management should ensure hired production workers achieve set target if all the necessary tools of work are provided so as to reduce borrowing bread.

value: Our production was being affect the power which sometimes has issues but we are trying our best to improve on production so as to reduce borrowing bread.
Our production was being affect the power failures

In a prior audit report Combined average yield for Unit I & 2 was 190.95 loaves per bag, average production was 121.51 bags equivalent to 78% of the set target of 156 bags, utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1 and there was 9 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period
Current
Target yield across all varieties was being achieved. However, the branch not achieving set target hence borrowing bread.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Production efficiency calculation from 1 March 2025 to 8 April 2025 was done to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.

        It was noted that the average production efficiency was 4.10 bags per production worker as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should allocate production workers as per production target shift wise so as to ensure set efficiency is achieved
attributes.effect: The branch did not achieve the set production efficiency target meaning that the cost of production was above set budget
attributes.remediation_plan: Production workers should be hired based on number of ovens in use and projected each day depending on sales

value: We are trying our best so as to achieve set target of 4.5 bags per production worker

Production efficiency was largely affected by frequent power failures and oven breakdowns.

        Frequent power failure was due to worn out kplc cable from transformer to the interchange which is in the process of repair.
From prior audit report average production efficiency was at 4.24 bags per production worker
Current
Test designed to check if each production achieve a set target of 4.5 bags in 8 hours
The set target was not being met
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Packing efficiency was calculated from 1 March 2025 to 8 April 2025 to determine if the packers hired were achieving the set packing efficiency of 97 crates per packer.

         It was noted that the average packing efficiency was 81 crates per packer as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation: Hiring of Packers shift wise should be guided by the number of bags produced in the prior shift. This will enable the branch to achieve set target
attributes.effect: Average packing efficiency was below the set target and this implies that packing cost was above the set budget hence an extra cost to the company
attributes.remediation_plan: Hiring of Packers shift wise should be guided by the number of bags produced in the prior shift. This will enable the branch to achieve set target

value: We will put more effort and follow up to improve our efficiency
More efforts to be enhanced to make sure packing efficiencies are achieved.
From prior audit report for the period 20th January to 27th February 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 85.97 crates per packer.
Current
This test is designed to ensure each wrapper packs 97 crates in eight hours
The wrappers hired were not achieving the set target hence an extra cost to the company
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Vehicle Mileage and Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of fuel consumption was done from 1 to 11 April 2025 to assess;

  •        Whether the standard fuel consumption set for each vehicle was being met

         It was noted that vehicles fuel consumption was fairly controlled during the period with Town, Mutuati 2 and Timau routes saving of 17.14 litres, 15.17litres and 17 litres respectively. Further it was noted that Githongo route had over consumed fuel by 20.14litres. An illustrated of the findings has been attached in appendix 1 below;
attributes.recommendation: A retest for Githongo route need to be done so as to establish the accurate standard rate to be used
attributes.effect: Githongo route consumption should be checked as the vehicle was using more fuel than set standard hence an extra cost of distribution in the route
attributes.remediation_plan: A retest for vehicles using more fuel need to be done so as to come up with accurate rates to be used even for those vehicles which save fuel the rate need to be revised

value: We will follow up with Githongo route vehicle with the help of the sales rep to check whether the set standard rate is accurate or a new one will be rest
This is noted and manager advised to make sure fuel is issued as per the kilometre covered in relation to consumption.
In a prior audit report all route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard except for M2, Timau and Tharaka route vehicles that had excess consumption of up to 152 Litres
Current
This is a test run to check fuel usage for distribution vehicles if they have used more fuel than set target
Some distribution vehicles were noted to be using more fuel than what they were supposed to use
Transport/Fleet Department

attributes.title: Generator Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
The generator consumption rate was reviewed from 1 to 11 April 2025 so as to determine the consumption rate. Average consumption for the period was 29.94litres per hour. During the period 100 litres of fuel had been purchased and the generator had run for 3.34hours.

         Audit noted that for the month of February 2025 genset consumption was 26.01L/Hr while for the month of March 2025 consumption was 37.29L/Hr, this meant that there was no consistency in consumption from one period to another.

         When the system hours were compared to the genset odometer physical reading, the system initial engine hours were 00hrs and final engine hours as 3.10.28 hrs.
attributes.recommendation:
The controls should be maintained by the management. The issue of different initial and final engine hours should be reported to the system provider so as to rectify it.

Generator consumption should be test for like  one hour with full load to determine the standard rate of consumption
attributes.effect:
The generator was well controlled. With different initial and final engine hours, it will be difficult for one to make a conclusion using the system engine hours and it will be difficult to know when exactly the next service could be done to the genset.

         When consumption is different from one month to another it raises queries on which one to follow to make decision.
attributes.remediation_plan: There's no set standard rate for generators. this standard need to be set so as it is easier to monitor fuel usage

value: Generator fuel consumption is well controlled as we only fuel after confirming the amount of fuel to buy.  We will inform the personnel responsible to communicate to the system provider to recheck the reading of the system. We will keep monitoring consumption from one month to another to see if they are consistency.
The controls will be maintained.
Current
This is a test designed to check generators fuel consumption whether within set standard
For the Meru generator there was no standard rate of consumption was set at the time of audit
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Returns
attributes.description:
Analysis of all bread retuned to the branch from 1 March 2025 to 9 April 2025 was done to determine the reasons with corresponding sum of bread returned when converted to 400gms.

         From the analysis a total of 5,351.25 pieces of loaves worth Ksh 283,616.25 (using Minishop price) were returned. If those with torn wrapper and oversupply were excluded it means that 3,937.75 (5,351.25-1,045-368.5) could be taken as damages hence a loss of revenue worth Ksh 208,700.75. Below is the illustration of the reasons for return and pieces of loaves in 400gms;

Note:  As per the system oversupply was in Tharaka, Chuka and Githongo.
attributes.recommendation:
The reason of bread returns should be captured in the system when the branch manager is offloading vehicles from routes so as to capture accurately the reason for return. This is because the sale crew may give a reason which might be inaccurate.

The manager should control bread balance and supervisor should check sell by date of packed bread to ensure there is no short expiry bread sent to the market.
attributes.effect:
The company is losing sales revenue when bread is returned to the branch due to reasons which can be controlled during production especially deformation, undersize, over/underbaked and short expiry.

         Oversupplying raises queries how more bread was supplied against orders placed.
attributes.remediation_plan: To reduce returns which contribute to loss of revenue, all production parameters should be followed to ensure bread produced is of good quality

value: We are trying to produce bread of good quality. Sometimes, the reasons given by sales crew may not be accurate. Therefore we request for these reasons to be captured when we are offloading the vehicles

All returns are captured with their correct reasons in the system and confirmed using the print out. In case the sales crew give wrong reason or not tallying the returns are received but charged to the crew
Current
This is a test designed to check number of loaves returned to the branch on daily basis and the monetary value forgone by the company
From the analysis if those with torn wrapper and oversupply were excluded it meant that 3,937.75 (5,351.25-1,045-368.5) could be taken as damages hence a loss of revenue worth Ksh 208,700.75
Operations/Production Department
